Award.AwardTitle: PRIMES: Program for Research In Mathematics, Engineering, and Science for high school Students
Award.AbstractNarration:
MIT PRIMES is a free, year-long research program for high school students at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. The goal of PRIMES is to give talented high school students a unique experience of real mathematical research, letting them discover the joy and beauty of mathematical exploration; to inspire them to pursue careers in the mathematical sciences; and to diversify the pool of students interested in mathematics by providing additional opportunities for promising students with underprivileged backgrounds. This project funds the local Mathematics Section of PRIMES. PRIMES students will work on their research projects during the academic year, aided by weekly meetings with their mentors (MIT Mathematics Department graduate students) on the MIT campus. The projects will be presented at annual PRIMES conferences, and final papers will be posted on the Program website and disseminated through arXiv.org and academic journals.

This project will fund research by high school students and their mentors in the following areas: quantum Schubert calculus, Ramsey multiplicity, the Richter-Thomassen conjecture and related topics, signatures of Hermitian forms arising in representation theory, structure of lower central series of associative algebras, and properties of closed polygonal paths with steps being roots of unity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
PRIMES is a free, year-long after-school research and enrichment program for high school students, based at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. It includes three main sections: MIT PRIMES offers research projects and guided reading to students from Greater Boston; PRIMES-USA is a national math research program for high school juniors; and PRIMES Circle is a math enrichment section for urban public high school students from the Boston area. In 2016-2018, more than 140 students did research and participated in enrichment activities in mathematics under the aegis of the PRIMES program.

PRIMES has developed an innovative approach, based on the combination of learning and research, which allows high school students to learn advanced areas of math and science and to participate in cutting-edge research within a year-long timeframe. Projects are formulated by university faculty and mentored by graduate students and postdoctoral scholars.

The results of PRIMES research have been widely disseminated at annual conferences at MIT, open to the public, posted online for free access, and submitted to academic journals for publication. In 2015-2018, PRIMES students produced 74 research papers, seven of which have already been published in academic journals. PRIMES students have won multiple awards at national and international science competitions.

PRIMES has explored various formats of research and enrichments activities, such as individual and group research projects, directed reading group, distance mentoring over telecommunication channels, studying advanced topics in a game-like setting, writing of research and expository papers, and conference presentations. PRIMES has established partnerships with faculty from Cornell University, Boise State University, Brandeis University, CUNY ? City College, SUNY at Stony Brook, University of Illinois at Chicago, University of Michigan, University of Washington, Stanford University, the University of Michigan, and UMass Amherst. The dissemination of the PRIMES experience encourages the creation of similar programs at other academic institutions.
